docs.snippet: Mr. THURLOW WEED AND THE HERALD.With reference to the partial retraction made by the Herald of the charges preferred against Mr. THURLOW WEED, the Journal of last evening says: It is quite true that for nearly thirty years we have been saying ugly...
docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. THURLOW WEED AND THE HERALD.With reference to the partial retraction made by the Herald of the charges preferred against Mr. THURLOW WEED, the Journal of last evening says: It is quite true that for nearly thirty years we have been saying ugly things of the Herald and its editor.

docs.snippet: Very interesting details of recent events in Mexico are given in the letters of our Special Correspondent at the capital. The civil war progresses with its usual catalogue of horrors. Assassinations, robberies, and outrages upon persons and property,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Very interesting details of recent events in Mexico are given in the letters of our Special Correspondent at the capital. The civil war progresses with its usual catalogue of horrors. Assassinations, robberies, and outrages upon persons and property, were of daily occurrence. Our latest advices from the City of Mexico are to Nov. 1.

docs.snippet: Ex-Governor GEORGE R. GILMER, who died on Wednesday at Lexington, Ga., was born in Wilkes County, now Oglethorpe, on the 11th of April, 1790. On account of ill health he was unable to prosecute his collegiate course, for which a thorough academical...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ex-Governor GEORGE R. GILMER, who died on Wednesday at Lexington, Ga., was born in Wilkes County, now Oglethorpe, on the 11th of April, 1790. On account of ill health he was unable to prosecute his collegiate course, for which a thorough academical education had fully fitted him.

docs.snippet: MEAKIM.--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 15, after a short illness, of pneumonia, ALEXANDER MESKIM, in the 45th year of his age. His friends, and those of his brother John; are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from No. 170 East 15th-st., on...
docs.lead_paragraph: MEAKIM.--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 15, after a short illness, of pneumonia, ALEXANDER MESKIM, in the 45th year of his age. His friends, and those of his brother John; are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from No. 170 East 15th-st., on Thursday, 17th inst., at ?? o'clock P.M. HYNE.--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 15, JOSEPH WM. HYNE, aged 63 years, 8 months and 19 days.

docs.snippet: From Washington. ILLNESS OF MR. DOUGLAS-HIS REPLY TO JUDGE BLACK-GATHERING OF CONGRESSMEN. WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Nov. 16. There is no perceptible change in the condition of the health of Mr. DOUGLAS to-day. When first stricken down he was employed...
docs.lead_paragraph: From Washington. ILLNESS OF MR. DOUGLAS-HIS REPLY TO JUDGE BLACK-GATHERING OF CONGRESSMEN. WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Nov. 16. There is no perceptible change in the condition of the health of Mr. DOUGLAS to-day. When first stricken down he was employed in preparing a reply to Judge BLACK'S rejoin or. It was issued to-day, in a pamphlet form, in an unfinished state.

docs.snippet: MESSRS. EDITORS: We are now on this coast about nine months, cruising most part of the time between Punta Arenas and Ralejo, watching, as we suppose, for fillibusters, of which there are on this coast, at present, very few. We arrived here on the...

headline.main: Naval.; CRUISE OF THE CYANE--THE SARANAC AND ST. MARY'S.

docs.lead_paragraph: MESSRS. EDITORS: We are now on this coast about nine months, cruising most part of the time between Punta Arenas and Ralejo, watching, as we suppose, for fillibusters, of which there are on this coast, at present, very few. We arrived here on the 12th of this month, and found the U. S; steamer Saranac in port, with orders for us to remain until the arrival of Flag-Officer MONTGOMERY in the Lancaster, from Valparaiso,

docs.snippet: Now that the Central Park is at last open to equestrians and carriages, the question how to make use of it becomes of immediate importance. Its vicinity will henceforth be in all probability a favorite place of residence for all who love daily...
docs.lead_paragraph: Now that the Central Park is at last open to equestrians and carriages, the question how to make use of it becomes of immediate importance. Its vicinity will henceforth be in all probability a favorite place of residence for all who love daily exercise on good roads. It will also, we have no doubt whatever, stimulate the last for riding on horseback, in which our young men have hitherto been lamentably deficient.

docs.snippet: From late Chinese journals, received by the Hungarian, we derive most interesting particulars of Mr. WARD'S visit to Peking, and of the ratification of the American Treaty. That ratification, as already known, was performed at Pei-tang, a village on...
docs.lead_paragraph: From late Chinese journals, received by the Hungarian, we derive most interesting particulars of Mr. WARD'S visit to Peking, and of the ratification of the American Treaty. That ratification, as already known, was performed at Pei-tang, a village on the Gulf of Pecheelee. It seems, from the accounts furnished, that the Emperor was very cordially disposed toward the American Minister,

docs.snippet: From Washington. ILLNESS OF JUDGE DOUGLAS-PATENTS ISSUED. WASHINGTON, Monday, Nov. 14. Judge DOUGLAS' early recovery of health was, on Saturday, anticipated by some of his most intimate friends. It is, however, reliably ascertained that he has been...
docs.lead_paragraph: From Washington. ILLNESS OF JUDGE DOUGLAS-PATENTS ISSUED. WASHINGTON, Monday, Nov. 14. Judge DOUGLAS' early recovery of health was, on Saturday, anticipated by some of his most intimate friends. It is, however, reliably ascertained that he has been extremely ill for the last three days. His physicians remained with him throughout last night, and, this morning, regard his condition about the same as yesterday, though, perhaps, a little more comfortable.
